(Copy)
Printed copy, enclosure to circular despatch to the Austalian colonies and New Zealand, for the text of which see M Hicks Beach to G. Bowen, 19 August 1878 (Unit 32A, VPRS 1987 despatches of the Secretary of State to the Governor, vol. 32, pt 2, July-December 1878, VA number, Public Record Office, Victoria). A working draft of this letter, addressed to the Under Secretary at the Colonial Office, R. Herbert, is in RBG Kew, Colonial floras, Kewensia, K9/655.59, ff.86-9. It differs in a number of respects from this distributed version, including deletion of a paragraph drawing attention to the importance of 'this establishment [i.e. the Royal Gardens, Kew] to our Colonial Empire'. For another major amendment made to the draft at Kew see note 3 below.
Royal Gardens, Kew
Sir,
It is with peculiar pleasure that I call your attention to the publication, during the present year, of the seventh and concluding volume of the "Flora Australiensis".

I believe that this work occupies a unique place in botanical literature. I am not aware of any other which, treating of the vegetation of so large a portion of the Earth's surface, has been successfully brought to a conclusion.

For the last sixteen years it has engaged the unremitting attention of its author, George Bentham Esq., F.R.S., late President of the Linnaean Society of London, who has carried on the studies necessary for its elaboration in the Library and Herbarium of the Royal Gardens so largely enriched by his own munificent gifts.

The utility of the work in describing in a uniform manner and in easily intelligible language the plants of a country so rich in vegetable products, cannot be over estimated, and it is a matter of daily experience that without such a work these plants could not be accurately discriminated, and could not therefore be turned to useful account with any certainty.

In a scientific point of view the "Flora Australiensis" is of inestimable value. It records the nature of the great bulk of the "Flora" with all the knowledge and skill of one of the greatest living sytematists, and this, while the natural conditions of the country can still be easily distinguished from the inevitable changes which must follow agricultural occupation and the operaton of a wide-spread commerce.

The accumulation in London, and principally at Kew, of the important botanical collections made by successive travellers and explorers, from the date of Captain Cook's voyages to the present day, have made the preparation in this country of the "Flora Australiensis" a matter of necessity. The labours of these men are bound up with the history of the Australian Colonies, and the mere barren enumeration of Australian plants, apart from the names of their first discoverers, would be an ungrateful obliteration of much that Australians will always hold in respect. Nor must it be forgotten, that many species obtained through the industry of these early collectors have never been gathered twice.

To no one was the force of these facts more apparent than to Baron von Mueller, the distinguished Government Botanist of Victoria; not merely did he therefore waive his own, in many respects preeminent claims to the authorship of the "Flora Australiesis" but, with singular generosity, he transmitted to this country his immense Australian Herbarium, the examination of which was indispensible to the proper elaboraton of the work. He, furthermore, allowed duplicate specimens to be taken from his collections for preservation at Kew as the authentic types upon which the descriptions published in the "Flora" had been based.

I trust that the completion of this, the most important of the series of Colonial Floras projected by my late father, will be recognised as evidence of the value of Baron von Mueller's services, and of the botanical Establishments of Melbourne and Kew in furthering the development of the inexhaustible vegetable resources of our Colonial empire.
The final paragraph of the working draft is written on plain paper slips, one pasted over the original text which is continued on a second pasted on to the verso. Use of a light box reveals that the original draft was a less overt hint at 'recognition':
[I] venture to suggest that a few words of congratulation addressed on behalf of Her Majesty’s government [to] Mr Bentham and Baron Mueller would be received by these gentlemen as grateful appreciation of their arduous unparalleled labour on behalf of [economic?] and [scientific] [...]

Robert Herbert's letter of acknowledgement to Hooker, dated Downing Street, 9 August 1878, is at RBG Kew, Colonial floras, ff. 90-1, and states that 'Sir Michael Hicks Beach will have pleasure in transmitting a copy of the correspondence to the Australian Governors and for communication to Dr Von Müeller who has so largely and generously contributed to the success of the undertaking'.
